Bachelor & Victor Kain

1.Victor Kain: The famous doctor Dankovsky... Your arrival is a great honour for us. Victor Kain at your service.

1.Victor Kain: The famous doctor Dankovsky... Your arrival is a great honour for us. Victor Kain at your service.

2.Bachelor: Daniil Dankovsky at yours.

2.Bachelor: Daniil Dankovsky at yours.

3.Victor Kain: I foresee that the things that have become ordinary for us will probably make you feel uncomfortable and disturbed. I would like to compensate for that impression. You know, our small community has fallen out of the loop... Time leaves us behind.

3.Victor Kain: I foresee that the things that have become ordinary for us will probably make you feel uncomfortable and disturbed. I would like to compensate for that impression. You know, our small community has fallen out of the loop... Time leaves us behind.

4.Bachelor: What do you mean?

4.Bachelor: What do you mean?

5.Victor Kain: I mean the traditions. Games that we play with passion will most likely be of no interest to you. The people you meet here may seem eccentric, naïve, or even... somewhat deranged. Please, take it easy on us, don't judge us too strictly.

5.Victor Kain: I mean the traditions. Games that we play with passion will most likely be of no interest to you. The people you meet here may seem eccentric, naïve, or even... somewhat deranged. Please, take it easy on us, don't judge us too strictly.

6.Bachelor: I will do my best not to disappoint you.

6.Bachelor: I will do my best not to disappoint you.

6.Bachelor: I hope we will be able to work in the atmosphere of mutual trust.

6.Bachelor: I hope we will be able to work in the atmosphere of mutual trust.

4.Bachelor: Don't worry.

4.Bachelor: Don't worry.

2.Bachelor: My pleasure.

2.Bachelor: My pleasure.

6.Bachelor: I will do my best not to disappoint you.

4.Bachelor: Don't worry.

4.Bachelor: Don't worry.

1.Victor Kain: So yesterday you managed to capture this disease? Or so I've heard, anyway. The town is abuzz with horrifying rumours of people being dissected alive... obviously, I don't believe those. The more dangerous kind of rumours are, it turns out, those about you acquiring a sample of infected blood...

1.Victor Kain: So yesterday you managed to capture this disease? Or so I've heard, anyway. The town is abuzz with horrifying rumours of people being dissected alive... obviously, I don't believe those. The more dangerous kind of rumours are, it turns out, those about you acquiring a sample of infected blood...

2.Bachelor: Quite so. The bacterium has been caught and encased in glass. I didn't do it on my own, though. I had help.

2.Bachelor: Quite so. The bacterium has been caught and encased in glass. I didn't do it on my own, though. I had help.

3.Victor Kain: More importantly, they say that you are now able to track down the shapeshifting disease carrier, сomparing their blood to that sample you obtained yesterday. If they are one of the townsfolk, it can't be that hard to recognize them.

3.Victor Kain: More importantly, they say that you are now able to track down the shapeshifting disease carrier, сomparing their blood to that sample you obtained yesterday. If they are one of the townsfolk, it can't be that hard to recognize them.

4.Bachelor: Also true.

4.Bachelor: Also true.

5.Victor Kain: This is a witch hunt in the making. As if dimwitted blackguards murdering women in the streets wasn't enough-it seems that our governor is now inclined to extend his greedy reach towards the town's notable people. Several young women stand accused after the Cathedral business.

5.Victor Kain: This is a witch hunt in the making. As if dimwitted blackguards murdering women in the streets wasn't enough-it seems that our governor is now inclined to extend his greedy reach towards the town's notable people. Several young women stand accused after the Cathedral business.

6.Bachelor: What happened at the Cathedral?

6.Bachelor: What happened at the Cathedral?

7.Victor Kain: A disease carrier got into the Cathedral last night. Everyone inside perished. Yes, yes, making it past your impregnable quarantine. Human or spirit, it's very clear now that this is an individual who can walk, and is probably quite malicious. Many people are revelling in this particular certainty.

7.Victor Kain: A disease carrier got into the Cathedral last night. Everyone inside perished. Yes, yes, making it past your impregnable quarantine. Human or spirit, it's very clear now that this is an individual who can walk, and is probably quite malicious. Many people are revelling in this particular certainty.

8.Bachelor: How so?

8.Bachelor: How so?

9.Victor Kain: An Inquisitor arrives tomorrow. It seems to me that someone wants to dispose of several young women before his coming. Presently the sword of justice hangs suspended above Yulia and Lara. They have been arrested, on Saburov's authority. But Vlad Olgimsky hasn't been idle either. If the girls survive until tomorrow, the Inquisitor will establish the truth, but... someone is eager to get ahead of him.

9.Victor Kain: An Inquisitor arrives tomorrow. It seems to me that someone wants to dispose of several young women before his coming. Presently the sword of justice hangs suspended above Yulia and Lara. They have been arrested, on Saburov's authority. But Vlad Olgimsky hasn't been idle either. If the girls survive until tomorrow, the Inquisitor will establish the truth, but... someone is eager to get ahead of him.

10.Bachelor: What does Olgimsky have to do with this?

10.Bachelor: What does Olgimsky have to do with this?

11.Victor Kain: The Olgimskys claim they can prove the girls' innocence. Perhaps they already know who the real culprit is. Somehow I have no doubt about that. I've heard the criminal is being kept inside the Termitary.

11.Victor Kain: The Olgimskys claim they can prove the girls' innocence. Perhaps they already know who the real culprit is. Somehow I have no doubt about that. I've heard the criminal is being kept inside the Termitary.

12.Bachelor: I see. I'll talk to Olgimsky.

12.Bachelor: I see. I'll talk to Olgimsky.

10.Bachelor: If they survive? What do you mean?

10.Bachelor: If they survive? What do you mean?

11.Victor Kain: Have you heard about these zealots, the exterminators? They are bent on burning the town clean of the disease, shouting something about the purifying fire. If someone passes names of these young women to the mob, they're doomed. They will burn in their own homes.

11.Victor Kain: Have you heard about these zealots, the exterminators? They are bent on burning the town clean of the disease, shouting something about the purifying fire. If someone passes names of these young women to the mob, they're doomed. They will burn in their own homes.

12.Bachelor: What can be done to help them?

12.Bachelor: What can be done to help them?

13.Victor Kain: The Olgimskys claim they can prove the girls' innocence. Perhaps they already know who the real culprit is. Somehow I have no doubt about that. I've heard the criminal is being kept inside the Termitary.

13.Victor Kain: The Olgimskys claim they can prove the girls' innocence. Perhaps they already know who the real culprit is. Somehow I have no doubt about that. I've heard the criminal is being kept inside the Termitary.

14.Bachelor: I see. I'll talk to Olgimsky.

14.Bachelor: I see. I'll talk to Olgimsky.

6.Bachelor: Who are these young women?

6.Bachelor: Who are these young women?

7.Victor Kain: Lara and Yulia's names are mentioned-and for good reason; their personal items were found on some of the dying people at the Cathedral. At least this is who governor Saburov intends to hand over.

7.Victor Kain: Lara and Yulia's names are mentioned-and for good reason; their personal items were found on some of the dying people at the Cathedral. At least this is who governor Saburov intends to hand over.

8.Bachelor: Strangely hurried, isn't it?

8.Bachelor: Strangely hurried, isn't it?

9.Victor Kain: Saburov is frightened. All his measures have abjectly failed. It is clear now that he is incapable of maintaining order in the town. The Cathedral tragedy was the last nail in his coffin. Under the circumstances, he has no options but to press harder.

9.Victor Kain: Saburov is frightened. All his measures have abjectly failed. It is clear now that he is incapable of maintaining order in the town. The Cathedral tragedy was the last nail in his coffin. Under the circumstances, he has no options but to press harder.

10.Bachelor: Is there anything I can do?

10.Bachelor: Is there anything I can do?

11.Victor Kain: Check on them-now that you have the capability. Hurry, before your discovery breeds baseless speculations. One would want to save innocent lives. Or else... nothing can be certain in a situation like this.

11.Victor Kain: Check on them-now that you have the capability. Hurry, before your discovery breeds baseless speculations. One would want to save innocent lives. Or else... nothing can be certain in a situation like this.

12.Bachelor: And you? Can you do anything?

12.Bachelor: And you? Can you do anything?

13.Victor Kain: The Olgimskys claim they can prove the girls' innocence. Perhaps they already know who the real culprit is. Somehow I have no doubt about that. I've heard the criminal is being kept inside the Termitary.

13.Victor Kain: The Olgimskys claim they can prove the girls' innocence. Perhaps they already know who the real culprit is. Somehow I have no doubt about that. I've heard the criminal is being kept inside the Termitary.

14.Bachelor: I see. I'll talk to Olgimsky.

14.Bachelor: I see. I'll talk to Olgimsky.

12.Bachelor: I will check on them if an opportunity presents itself. I don't believe they are guilty, and I assume the governor has no illusions on the subject either.

12.Bachelor: I will check on them if an opportunity presents itself. I don't believe they are guilty, and I assume the governor has no illusions on the subject either.

9.Victor Kain: He sent Isidor home. Then, an hour later, he came to this hall to see us. He announced his plans to withdraw to the Focus and receive no one. He told us not to approach the Focus and to fast for a week, partaking of neither meat nor water. Then, in the morning, he was found dead.

9.Victor Kain: He sent Isidor home. Then, an hour later, he came to this hall to see us. He announced his plans to withdraw to the Focus and receive no one. He told us not to approach the Focus and to fast for a week, partaking of neither meat nor water. Then, in the morning, he was found dead.

10.Bachelor: How was he found?

10.Bachelor: How was he found?

11.Victor Kain: The servants discovered him in the morning. The room had been ransacked. Everything that was breakable had been broken. His disfigured, contorted body bore signs of terrible suffering. His neck was twisted, his spine broken... I think. No one has touched the body. It is currently inside the Focus and will remain there for the prescribed amount of time.

18.Bachelor: How was the body discovered?

18.Bachelor: How was the body discovered?

19.Victor Kain: The servants discovered him in the morning. The room had been ransacked. Everything that was breakable had been broken. His disfigured, contorted body bore signs of terrible suffering. His neck was twisted, his spine broken... I think. No one has touched the body. It is currently inside the Focus and will remain there for the prescribed amount of time.

15.Victor Kain: The servants discovered him in the morning. The room had been ransacked. Everything that was breakable had been broken. His disfigured, contorted body bore signs of terrible suffering. His neck was twisted, his spine broken... I think. No one has touched the body. It is currently inside the Focus and will remain there for the prescribed amount of time.

8.Bachelor: When was Simon last seen?

8.Bachelor: When was Simon last seen?

9.Victor Kain: He sent Isidor home. Then, an hour later, he came to this hall to see us. He announced his plans to withdraw to the Focus and receive no one. He told us not to approach the Focus and to fast for a week, partaking of neither meat nor water. Then, in the morning, he was found dead.

9.Victor Kain: He sent Isidor home. Then, an hour later, he came to this hall to see us. He announced his plans to withdraw to the Focus and receive no one. He told us not to approach the Focus and to fast for a week, partaking of neither meat nor water. Then, in the morning, he was found dead.

10.Bachelor: How was he found?

10.Bachelor: How was he found?

11.Victor Kain: The servants discovered him in the morning. The room had been ransacked. Everything that was breakable had been broken. His disfigured, contorted body bore signs of terrible suffering. His neck was twisted, his spine broken... I think. No one has touched the body. It is currently inside the Focus and will remain there for the prescribed amount of time.

16.Bachelor: How was the body discovered?

16.Bachelor: How was the body discovered?

17.Victor Kain: The servants discovered him in the morning. The room had been ransacked. Everything that was breakable had been broken. His disfigured, contorted body bore signs of terrible suffering. His neck was twisted, his spine broken... I think. No one has touched the body. It is currently inside the Focus and will remain there for the prescribed amount of time.

18.Bachelor: How was the body discovered?

19.Victor Kain: The servants discovered him in the morning. The room had been ransacked. Everything that was breakable had been broken. His disfigured, contorted body bore signs of terrible suffering. His neck was twisted, his spine broken... I think. No one has touched the body. It is currently inside the Focus and will remain there for the prescribed amount of time.

It is currently inside the Focus and will remain there for the prescribed amount of time.

9.Victor Kain: He sent Isidor home. Then, an hour later, he came to this hall to see us. He announced his plans to withdraw to the Focus and receive no one. He told us not to approach the Focus and to fast for a week, partaking of neither meat nor water. Then, in the morning, he was found dead.

9.Victor Kain: He sent Isidor home. Then, an hour later, he came to this hall to see us. He announced his plans to withdraw to the Focus and receive no one. He told us not to approach the Focus and to fast for a week, partaking of neither meat nor water. Then, in the morning, he was found dead.

10.Bachelor: How was he found?

10.Bachelor: How was he found?

11.Victor Kain: The servants discovered him in the morning. The room had been ransacked. Everything that was breakable had been broken. His disfigured, contorted body bore signs of terrible suffering. His neck was twisted, his spine broken... I think. No one has touched the body. It is currently inside the Focus and will remain there for the prescribed amount of time.

11.Victor Kain: The servants discovered him in the morning. The room had been ransacked. Everything that was breakable had been broken. It is currently inside the Focus and will remain there for the prescribed amount of time.

12.Bachelor: Do you suspect anyone?

17.Victor Kain: The servants discovered him in the morning. The room had been ransacked. Everything that was breakable had been broken. It is currently inside the Focus and will remain there for the prescribed amount of time.

14.Bachelor: How was the body discovered?

15.Victor Kain: The servants discovered him in the morning. The room had been ransacked. Everything that was breakable had been broken. His disfigured, contorted body bore signs of terrible suffering. His neck was twisted, his spine broken... I think. No one has touched the body. It is currently inside the Focus and will remain there for the prescribed amount of time.

15.Victor Kain: The servants discovered him in the morning. The room had been ransacked. Everything that was breakable had been broken. 5.Victor Kain: Georgiy holds your abilities in very high regard. He wants you to reconstruct the crime on your own and is reluctant to let you in on things that will change your entire worldview... probably putting you on a false trail in the process.

7.Victor Kain: A peculiar kind of pest broke out among factory workers five years ago. Not here but in the poor districts. Isidor took care of it quickly. There were many deaths, but only in the Crude Sprawl-a district that borders on the Abattoir. But The Willows is on the riverbank; the infection never made it that far. An odd story, don't you think?

He thinks he can terrorize the people, but all he'll accomplish is to turn the people into a gang of armed thugs. By tomorrow I'll have pressed this matter and freed the innocent.

6.Bachelor: The Executors guarding the prisoners happily take bribes when the governor isn't looking. They want ten thousand per person.

6.Bachelor: The Executors guarding the prisoners happily take bribes when the governor isn't looking. They want ten thousand per person.

7.Victor Kain: We have barely any money left. Fifty five thousand-that's all we have left right now... Try intimidating the Executors; namedrop the Kains! Tell them we know all about their schemes. That they themselves will end up behind bars unless they let these people out of jail!

8.Bachelor: They are masked. No one has seen an Executor's face.

9.Victor Kain: Fine... Take twenty five thousand. At least bail out someone, several people. And I think I will still draft that ultimatum to Saburov. If we survive the epidemic, he and us, I swear we'll remind him of all this!

5.Victor Kain: Since his childhood, my brother Georgiy had had rather simplistic views on the connection between the human body and the soul. 1.Victor Kain: You are the last friend our family has. I hope our attachment to you doesn't look obtrusive.

2.Bachelor: It requires too much from me. I'm not comfortable with it.

2.Bachelor: No, not at all.

1.Victor Kain: There you are, Bachelor Dankosvky. You see, I wanted to avoid all the unnecessary sentimental talk... But it has come to be that the Kains are getting ready to sleep. And it will come to be that only Maria will rise from that sleep. If you leave us, we will probably perish.

1.Victor Kain: There you are, Bachelor Dankosvky. You see, I wanted to avoid all the unnecessary sentimental talk... But it has come to be that the Kains are getting ready to sleep. And it will come to be that only Maria will rise from that sleep. If you leave us, we will probably perish.

2.Bachelor: What does that mean? Are you intending to die?

2.Bachelor: What does that mean? Are you intending to die?

3.Victor Kain: We are back at the starting point now. We deal with the issue of death differently. When the original identity is extinguished and an entirely new one arises in its place-is that death? Is madness not a form of death? Is loss of memory not the true death?

3.Victor Kain: We are back at the starting point now. We deal with the issue of death differently. When the original identity is extinguished and an entirely new one arises in its place-is that death? Is madness not a form of death? Is loss of memory not the true death?

4.Bachelor: That's just philosophy... Surely you didn't summon me here for that!

4.Bachelor: That's just philosophy... Surely you didn't summon me here for that!

3.Victor Kain: A Mistress grants life to anything she touches with her hand, her words, or even her thoughts. Like that ancient king who turned bread, trees, and water into gold with a touch of his hand. But the king's touch turned the living into the dead. A Mistress does the opposite.

3.Victor Kain: A Mistress grants life to anything she touches with her hand, her words, or even her thoughts. Like that ancient king who turned bread, trees, and water into gold with a touch of his hand. But the king's touch turned the living into the dead. A Mistress does the opposite.

4.Bachelor: How does it work?

5.Victor Kain: That I do not know. I know that it happens, and know that there is no greater joy in the world. A Mistress can hold a toy in her hands, and it will come to life. She can think about it, and the doll will remember its family history to the seventh generation. She can see it in a dream-and the doll will be able to create.

1.Victor Kain: Everything will be decided tomorrow. The black muzzles of the cannons ready to begin the bombardment... so this is what the dark void of death looks like. So the true Nothingness, unlike true magic, can indeed be firmly grasped-with a steel ring, and one of a not particularly large calibre at that!

1.Victor Kain: Everything will be decided tomorrow. The black muzzles of the cannons ready to begin the bombardment... so this is what the dark void of death looks like. 15.Victor Kain: You cannot know the answer to this question. Had my daughter not fallen in love with you, you wouldn't have been allowed to ask even the questions you've asked so far. Why have you come here, Bachelor Dankovsky?

16.Bachelor: I want to know the truth about Simon.

16.Bachelor: I want to know the truth about Simon.

17.Victor Kain: So you want to know the truth about Simon? So be it. You will. The truth is that Georgiy Kain, who so ardently desired eternal life for his brother, has committed himself in entirety to Simon's Memory. He is imbued completely with memories of him. That is what Katerina saw... but she is very sloppy with her visions.

11.Victor Kain: Memory is the very fine particles of a person that exist between that which is the person and all that isn't. Some have the ability to collect those particles. For as long as people are able to retain the particles inside themselves, the person is not dead. They remain here, but their soul is not imprisoned. It flies off to where it's supposed to be.

That is what Katerina saw... but she is very sloppy with her visions.

13.Victor Kain: Memory is the very fine particles of a person that exist between that which is the person and all that isn't. Some have the ability to collect those particles. For as long as people are able to retain the particles inside themselves, the person is not dead. They remain here, but their soul is not imprisoned. It flies off to where it's supposed to be.

That is what Katerina saw... but she is very sloppy with her visions.

13.Victor Kain: Memory is the very fine particles of a person that exist between that which is the person and all that isn't. Some have the ability to collect those particles. For as long as people are able to retain the particles inside themselves, the person is not dead. They remain here, but their soul is not imprisoned. It flies off to where it's supposed to be.

11.Victor Kain: Memory is the very fine particles of a person that exist between that which is the person and all that isn't. Some have the ability to collect those particles. For as long as people are able to retain the particles inside themselves, the person is not dead. They remain here, but their soul is not imprisoned. It flies off to where it's supposed to be.

9.Victor Kain: Memory is the very fine particles of a person that exist between that which is the person and all that isn't. Some have the ability to collect those particles. For as long as people are able to retain the particles inside themselves, the person is not dead. They remain here, but their soul is not imprisoned. It flies off to where it's supposed to be.

9.Victor Kain: She was a radiantly beautiful woman. A dark chestnut with an intricate hairdo. Her eyes were deep and of the colour of French plum; her features were noble. Her only failing was the tendency to blow her nostrils, but that was hardly noticeable-they were thin and tight and elegant.
